name: The American Experience in Movies Multiple Choice Quiz | Movies | 10 Questions

questions.text: "Plymouth Adventure" dramatized the journey of the Pilgrims as early American colonists. Who starred in the movie?
questions.explanation:
Spencer Tracy.

	They must have been hardy adventurers to cross the Atlantic in that little ship.

questions.text: America's greatest crisis may have been its Civil War - nowhere more dramatically shown than in "Gone With the Wind". Who played the "white trash" that wanted to buy Tara after the war had ended?
questions.explanation:
Victor Jory.

	All were in the movie - Howard in a big role, the others in small ones. Jory played the character in question.

questions.text: The Civil War was also a time for heroes and martyrs. "Abe Lincoln in Illinois" shows the early days of America's most famous president. In that context, what is true about the actor, Raymond Massey, who did such a fine job as Abe?
options: He was born in Great Britain
questions.explanation:
He was born in Canada.

	Massey was superb in the role - but the man who played one of our greatest presidents was Canadian-born.

questions.text: The taming of the West was impressively shown in "How The West Was Won" - and not so impressively shown in "Cheyenne Autumn". Which actor or actress did NOT appear in both movies?
questions.explanation:
Debbie Reynolds.

	"West" was a fine movie with an all-star cast. "Autumn" dealt with a noble theme - the mistreatment of the American Indians - but was  less-than-outstanding as a movie.

questions.text: The West was not the only part of the country that needed law and order - especially in the roaring twenties. Who starred in "The FBI Story"?
questions.explanation:
James Stewart.

	The FBI brings law and order - or so the story goes - in conflicts with Ma Barker, John Dillinger, etc. (Also, Rod Steiger in "Al Capone").

questions.text: "JFK" dramatized one of the worst moments in American history. Kevin Costner starred as Jim Garrison; who played his wife?
questions.explanation:
Sissy Spacek.

	The movie may have been historically flawed - but so was the hokey version that the government pawned off as "the truth".

questions.text: "Mississippi Burning" was an excellent dramatization of the problems involved in the Civil Rights movement. What was the primary reason that the FBI agents in the movie descended on Mississippi?
options: Overt opposition to integration by the Governor
Problems with integration at a university campus
questions.explanation:
Disappearance of three young men.

	Two white males and one black male disappeared - and were later found to have been killed. Fine job by Gene Hackman and Willem Dafoe.

questions.text: The Vietnam war tore America apart. Which of these Vietnam movies included Bruce Dern and Jon Voight in the cast?
questions.explanation:
Coming Home.

	With Jane Fonda. The impact of war lingers after combat ends.

questions.text: "All the President's Men" was a fine rendition of the Watergate story. Where did Woodward (Redford) meet Deep Throat in the movie?
questions.explanation:
Underground garage.

	At night in the shadowy darkness of the underground garage. Hal Holbrook played him.

questions.text: The poverty of hard times was depicted in "The Grapes of Wrath". Who wrote the novel?
questions.explanation:
John Steinbeck.

	Henry Fonda, Jane Darwell, John Carradine. Good movie.
